answer_html: Notice that the provided information for \(f(1,0)=0\) was unnecessary.
answer_latex: Notice that the provided information for $f(1,0)=0$ was unnecessary.
hints_html: How does the chain rule works when dealing with functions of several variables?
hints_latex:
How does the chain rule works when dealing with functions of several
variables?
hints_raw: How does the chain rule works when dealing with functions of several variables?
question: 9 (g)
sols_html:
The function f depends on the variables x and y which themselves are functions of the variable t. We have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle z(t) = f(x(t),y(t)) \quad\text{and}\quad x(t) = e^{3t} \quad\text{and}\quad y(t) = \sin(2t)\end{aligned}\]

Now, using the chain rule for multivariable functions we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dz}{dt}(t) = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x(t),y(t))\frac{dx}{dt}(t) + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x(t),y(t))\frac{dy}{dt}(t)\end{aligned}\]

which using the notation as in the question statement gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle z'(t) = f_X(x(t),y(t))\,x'(t) + f_Y\left(x(t),y(t)\right)\,y'(t)\end{aligned}\]

Now we just want to know what’s going on at t = 0. We have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x(0) = e^0 = 1 \quad\text{and}\quad y(0)=\sin(0)=0\end{aligned}\]

and since

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x'(t) = 3e^{3t} \quad\text{and}\quad y'(t)=2\cos(2t)\end{aligned}\]

we have

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x'(0) = 3 \quad\text{and}\quad y'(0)=2\end{aligned}\]

So we can conclude that

\[\begin{aligned} z'(0) &= f_X(1,0) \cdot 3 + f_Y(1,0) \cdot 2\\ &= 3 \cdot 3 + (-1) \cdot 2\\ &= 7\end{aligned}\]

.

Notice that the provided information for \(f(1,0)=0\) was unnecessary.
sols_raw:
The function ''f'' depends on the variables ''x'' and ''y'' which themselves are functions of the variable ''t''. We have
:<math>\displaystyle
z(t) = f(x(t),y(t)) \quad\text{and}\quad x(t) = e^{3t} \quad\text{and}\quad y(t) = \sin(2t)
</math>
Now, using the chain rule for multivariable functions we obtain
:<math>
\frac{dz}{dt}(t) = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x(t),y(t))\frac{dx}{dt}(t) + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x(t),y(t))\frac{dy}{dt}(t)
</math>
which using the notation as in the question statement gives
:<math>\displaystyle
z'(t) = f_X(x(t),y(t))\,x'(t) + f_Y\left(x(t),y(t)\right)\,y'(t)
</math>

Now we just want to know what's going on at ''t'' = 0. We have
:<math>\displaystyle
x(0) = e^0 = 1 \quad\text{and}\quad y(0)=\sin(0)=0
</math>
and since
:<math>\displaystyle
x'(t) = 3e^{3t} \quad\text{and}\quad y'(t)=2\cos(2t)
</math>
we have
:<math>\displaystyle
x'(0) = 3 \quad\text{and}\quad y'(0)=2
</math>

So we can conclude that
:<math>\displaystyle \begin{align}
z'(0) &= f_X(1,0) \cdot 3 + f_Y(1,0) \cdot 2\\
&= 3 \cdot 3 + (-1) \cdot 2\\
& = 7
\end{align}</math>.

Notice that the provided information for <math>f(1,0)=0</math> was unnecessary.
statement_html:
Each of the short-answer questions below is worth 5 points. Put your answer in the box provided and show your work. No credit will be given for the answer without the correct accompanying work.

You are given a function \(f\) satisfying \(f(1,0) = 0,\) \(f_x(1,0) = 3,\) and \(f_y(1,0) = -1.\) Find \(z'(0)\) if

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{ z(t) = f(e^{3t}, \sin (2t)) }.\end{aligned}\]

You are given a function <math> f </math> satisfying <math> f(1,0) = 0, </math> <math> f_x(1,0) = 3, </math> and <math> f_y(1,0) = -1. </math>  Find <math> z'(0) </math> if

:<math>
\displaystyle{ z(t) = f(e^{3t}, \sin (2t)) }.
</math>
